examples.note: Example sentence using the word in a context of condemnation.

verb_forms.present_indicative: damno, damnas, damnat, damnamus, damnatis, damnant
verb_forms.imperfect_indicative: damnabam, damnabas, damnabat, damnabamus, damnabatis, damnabant
verb_forms.future_indicative: damnabo, damnabis, damnabit, dabnabimus, dabnabitis, dabnabunt
verb_forms.perfect_indicative: damnavi, damnavisti, damnavit, damnavimus, damnavistis, damnaverunt
verb_forms.pluperfect_indicative: damnaveram, damnaveras, damnaverat, damnaveramus, damnaveratis, damnaverant
verb_forms.future_perfect_indicative: damnavero, damnaveris, damnaverit, damnaverimus, damnaveritis, damnaverint
verb_forms.present_subjunctive: demnem, demnes, demnet, demnemus, demnetis, demnent
verb_forms.imperfect_subjunctive: damnare, damnares, damnaret, damnaremus, damnaretis, damnarent
verb_forms.perfect_subjunctive: damnaverim, damnaveris, damnaverit, damnaverimus, damnaveritis, damnaverint
verb_forms.pluperfect_subjunctive: damnavissem, damnavisses, damnavisset, damnavissemus, damnavissetis, damnavissent

usage_notes.explanation: *Damno* is a Latin verb meaning to condemn or damn. It is the root of the English word *damn*. It is used in legal, moral, and religious contexts.
